gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: The home page for the Northwest Knowledge Network

gmd:metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19115-2 Geographic Information - Metadata Part 2 Extensions for imagery and gridded data

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Salmon River RCC Transported Organic Matter

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The data presented here represent the transported organic matter data collected from 1976 to 1979 along the Salmon River mainstem. These data were part of the original river continuum concept (RCC) project. Seven sites were sampled seasonally over multiple years. Four sites on the upper Salmon River mainstem (i.e., Camp, Smiley, Obsidian, and Casino) were sampled in Feb/Mar, May/Jun, Jul/Aug, and Sept/Oct of 1976. Four sites on the mid to lower Salmon River were sampled in March/April, July, and September/October of 1977 (i.e., Casino, Deadman's hole, Shoup, and Slate). Additional samples were collected in 1978 and 1979 at various sites and seasons. Some of these additional sites were not included in the RCC data papers and are unpublished. Eight different size classes of transport were analyzed separately for ash free dry mass and chlorophyll-a. These data formed the basis of the following manuscripts: Minshall GW, Petersen RC, Bott TL, Cushing CE, Cummins KW, Vannote RL, Sedell JR (1992) Stream ecosystem dynamics of the Salmon River, Idaho: An 8th order system. J. N. Am. Benthol. Soc. 11:111-137 Minshall GW, Petersen RC, Cummins KW, Bott TL, Sedell JR, Cushing CE, Vannote RL (1983) Interbiome comparison of stream ecosystem dynamics. Ecol. Monogr. 53:1-25

gmd:keyword.gco:CharacterString: Water Resources in a Changing Climate

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: constraints: Data will be provided to all who agree to appropriately acknowledge the National Science Foundation (NSF), Idaho EPSCoR and the individual investigators responsible for the data set. By downloading these data and using them to produce further analysis and/or products, users agree to appropriately acknowledge the National Science Foundation (NSF), Idaho EPSCoR and the individual investigators responsible for the data set. | Use constraints: Acceptable uses of data provided by Idaho EPSCoR include any academic, research, educational, governmental, recreational, or other not-for-profit activities. Any use of data provided by the Idaho EPSCoR must acknowledge Idaho EPSCoR and the funding source(s) that contributed to the collection of the data. Users are expected to inform the Idaho EPSCoR Office and the PI(s) responsible for the data of any work or publications based on data provided. | For more information, see http://www.idahoepscor.org/uploads/ID%20EPSCoR%20Data%20Policies%20V5%20Final.pdf

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: This ISO metadata record is derived from an EML metadata record that may be more complete. The EML metadata record is included in the digital download in both XML and HTML formats and contains additional descriptive information about the dataset that is not represented in this ISO record.

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: The home page for the Northwest Knowledge Network

gmd:fileDecompressionTechnique.gco:CharacterString: The files are compressed in standard ZIP format.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: 1976 Transport Sampling Methods and Site Locations Transported organic matter (TOM) was sampled at the upper sites in 1976 (Camp, Smiley, Obsidian, and Casino) using the methods detailed below. Chl-a and AFDM analyses were conducted on all field collected samples during the 1976 sampling trips. The following methods are from an unpublished manuscript of Jim Brock's. In the original field notes, these samples are considered quantitative samples that were collected continuously. Sites were selected primarily for ease of access during the winter months. In general, the sites were named after the nearest tributary or town. Therefore, many of these sites are near roads, bridges, or campgrounds. Also, in some seasons they did not sample Casino (Oct 1978) and used a sample from Clayton Bridge as a surrogate. Additionally, the Slate RCC site was mostly at the Camas gravel mine, but they used the sportsman access just downriver for a sample. In the field notes these are considered quantitative samples that were collected continuously. Although TOM was split into 8 size fractions, for the publications it was lumped together as CTOM (≥1mm), FTOM (<1mm and ≥52µm), and UFTOM (<52µm and ≥0.45µm). The 8 size classes were as follows: a. >16mm b. >4mm c. >1mm d. >500µm e. >250µm f. >100µm g. >52µm h. >0.45µm “Three separate procedures were employed to sample the full range of transported material, which was fractionated into 8 particle sizes. The three largest particle sizes (>16, 16-4, and 4-1mm), referred to collectively as CTOM (coarse transported organic matter), were sampled by means of a section of PVC pipe (1m X 0.25 m diameter) fitted with a conical 1-mm mesh net and suspended in the water column at approximately 0.6 depth. Volume filtered was calculated as the product of time, cross sectional area, and velocity through the pipe, measured with a digital flowmeter (General Oceanics 2030) or, occasionally, a small Ott current meter. Three approximately equal time sample periods were even spaced throughout the 24-h day during winter and spring. Continuous 24-hr CTOM sampling was done in the summer and autumn. The water column CTOM sampled was augmented during autumn by a floating drift net, which sampled the upper 15 cm of the water column (Winger 1968). Volume filtered was as above. [NOTE: The samples were split into finer resolution size fractions after their initial collections. Therefore, the same sample time, sample volumes, and replicate counts are recorded for these various finer resolution size fractions within the broad CTOM category. Because the net would clog, they could not take a continous 24-hr sample in a given day. They had to stop sampling and process them in two parts. These parts were treated as separate replicates because they were taken at different times and sampled different volumes. J. Davis addendum]. Fine transported organic matter (FTOM) was sampled differently in order to overcome difficulties with frequent clogging of nets by small particles. At Camp and Smiley, two small submersible pumps were secured at approx. 0.6 depth in a riffle at mid- and quarter-stream. Three pumps placed at equal intervals to midstream were used at Obsidian and Casino. Pump output was carried by hoses (1.9 cm diam) to a filter box located on shore. The plexiglass box held monofilament screens of decreasing mesh size (1mm, 500 µm, 250µm, 102µm, and 52µm mesh) which gravity sieved the seston into four FTOM size fractions. A filter box holding screens with 203 cm^2 area was used in winter. The box was enlarged to hold 703cm^2 screens for the remaining three seasons in order to minimize clogging. Volume filtered was calculated by rating pump output at beginning and end of each pumping period. Normally, the water column was sampled for FTOM at 0700, 1400, and 2200 hr, each for 2 hour duration. During spring run-off, high flows made it impossible to establish pump transects at the Obsidian and Casino sites. This problem was circumvented by use of a torpedo shaped enclosure which held a submersible pump and small filter box. The sampler was deployed from a bridge, and the pump operated for 15 minutes to obtain a representative sample of seston. Sample volume could be determined since all pumped water was screened. Short (1-hr grab) FTOM samples in the spring and autumn were collected with this device. [NOTE: The samples were split into finer resolution size fractions after their initial collections. Therefore, the same sample time, sample volumes, and replicate counts are recorded for these various finer resolution size fractions within the broad FTOM category. Because the sieves would clog, they could not take a continous 24-hr sample in a given day. They had to stop sampling and process them in two parts. These parts were treated as separate replicates because they were taken at different times and sampled different volumes.J. Davis addendum]. Ultrafine transported organic matter (UFTOM) and dissolved organic matter (DOM) were obtained with the FTOM pumps. Three times per day, corresponding to the beginning of each FTOM sample period, 6 L of water were pumped into a 19L carboy. At the end of the day, the carboy was shaken vigorously and the water poured through a 52µm monofilament net. This water was filtered quantitatively under approximately 30mm Hg vacuum onto 3 pre-ashed, tared, Whatman GF/C filters. A portion of the filtrate as collected in glass BOD bottles, and preserved with conc HCL (final pH = 2) for subsequent DOM analysis. [Note: They sometimes processed three UFTOM filters separately during a given day. J. Davis addendum]. Seston was removed from the CTOM and FTOM screens and frozen, after removing as much water as possible. The three samples per day of CTOM, FTOM, and UTOM were processed separately in winter and spring to estimate diel variance for each size fraction. During summer and fall, the three daily samples were combined, yielding a single daily composite sample for each size. In the laboratory, CTOM samples were thawed and fractionated into 1-4 mm, 4-16mm, and >16mm subsamples prior to pigment extraction. Chlorophyll, dry weight, and ash-free dry mass (AFDM) for all particulate samples were determined as follows. After thawing, chlorophyll-a and phaeophytion were estimated using Lorenzen’s technique, with extraction in 90% acetone and absorbance determined on a Beckman DB-G spectrophotometer. Percent pigment degradation was calculated as phaeophytin divided by (phaeophyton + chlorophyll-a). Samples with acetone were transferred to tared crucibles, dried to a constant weight at 60ºC, then ashed at 525ºC for at least 4 hrs. Weight loss during combustion is reported as AFDW. DOM samples were concentrated to approximately 3ml by dreeze drying, and three replicates of each sample were analyzed using a Dohrman DC.50 Total Carbon Analyzer. DOM was assumed to be 50% organic carbon (Birge and Juday 1934). Stream discharge for each sample day was determined from stage: discharge relationships based on approximately 10 measurements (Buchanon and Somers 1969) made over the full range of flows at each station. Daily discharge values for the Salmon River at Stanley were estimated from a correlation between discharge at the discontinued Stanley USGS station and the active USGS gage at Salmon, Idaho, based on historic data from 1926-1960 (C. W. Alexander, USGS, Portland OR pers. comm.). Sample periods during 1976 were in February-March (Winter), May-June (Spring), July-August (Summer), and September-October (autumn). The winter, summer, and autumn samples consisted of 3-5 consecutive days at each station. In autumn several supplemental grab transport samples were collected from each site to aid in characterization of seasonal patterns. In spring, the five sample days were distributed with several consecutive days on the rising limb of the runoff hydrograph, and additional samples taken later in the month to coincide with receding flows.”

1977 Transport Sampling Methods and Site Locations Four sites were sampled along the mainstem (Casino, Deadman's Hole, Shoup, and Slate) in March 24th to April 17th, July 7th to July 19th, and September 18th to October 9th 1977. They did not collect a winter sample (late Feb to early March before run-off) in 1977. In 1976, the March sample was considered a 'winter' sample and the July sample was considered the 'summer' sample. In 1977, the March/April sample was considered the 'spring' sample, the July sample was considered the 'summer' sample, and the September/October sample was considered the 'fall' sample. Sites were selected primarily for ease of access during the winter months. In general, the sites were named after the nearest tributary or town. Therefore, many of these sites are near roads, bridges, or campgrounds. Also, in some seasons they did not sample Casino (Oct 1978) and used a sample from Clayton Bridge as a surrogate. Additionally, the Slate RCC site was mostly at the Camas gravel mine, but they used the sportsman access just downriver for a sample. In the field notes these are considered quantitative samples that were collected continuously. They sometimes also labeled Deadman's hole as Bayhorse in the field notes, but it was the same location. Although TOM was split into 8 size fractions, for the publications it was lumped into CTOM (≥1mm), FTOM (<1mm and ≥52µm), and UFTOM (<52µm and ≥0.45µm). The 8 size classes were as follows: a. >16mm b. >4mm c. >1mm d. >500µm e. >250µm f. >100µm g. >52µm h. >0.45µm Methods during 1976 differed slightly from 1977. Although they calculated ash-free dry mass (AFDM) on the 1977 field collected transport samples, they did not analyze the field-collected transported organic matter for chl-a. Instead, they analyzed samples from concurrent metabolism chamber sampling (see Bott et al. 1985), which were size fractionated to CTOM, FTOM, and UFTOM. They calculated chl-a to ash-free dry mass (AFDM) ratios on the samples collected for the chambers. Then, by multiplying it by the field collected AFDM values, they could backcalculate the amount of chl-a in the field samples. Because they used the average chl-a to AFDM ratios for the chamber data, the Excel spreadsheets lists the same ratio for multiple field collected samples. The following is quoted from Jim Brock's unpublished manuscript. “Three separate procedures were employed to sample the full range of transported material, which was fractionated into 8 particle sizes. The three largest particle sizes (>16, 16-4, and 4-1mm), referred to collectively as CTOM (coarse transported organic matter), were sampled with a metal drift frame with an attached torpedo current meter (General Oceanics) and 1-mm mesh conical net. The long axis was perpendicular to the substrate and captured the entire water column. Volume filtered was calculated as the product of time, cross sectional area, and velocity through the pipe, measured with a digital flowmeter (General Oceanics 2030) or, occasionally, a small Ott current meter. Three approximately equal time sample periods were even spaced throughout the 24-h day during winter and spring. Continuous 24-hr CTOM sampling was done in the summer and autumn. The water column CTOM sampled was augmented during autumn by a floating drift net, which sampled the upper 15 cm of the water column (Winger 1968). Volume filtered was as above. [NOTE: The samples were split into finer resolution size fractions after their initial collections. Therefore, the same sample time, sample volumes, and replicate counts are recorded for these various finer resolution size fractions within the broad CTOM category. J. Davis addendum]. Fine transported organic matter (FTOM) was sampled differently in order to overcome difficulties with frequent clogging of nets by small particles. Three pumps placed at equal intervals to midstream were used at Obsidian and Casino. Pumps were placed at 0.60 of the water depth. Pump output was carried by hoses (1.9 cm diam) to a filter box located on shore. The plexiglass box held monofilament screens of decreasing mesh size (1mm, 500 µm, 250µm, 102µm, and 52µm mesh) which gravity sieved the seston into four FTOM size fractions. A filter box holding screens with 203 cm^2 area was used in winter. The box was enlarged to hold 703cm^2 screens for the remaining three seasons in order to minimize clogging. Volume filtered was calculated by rating pump output at beginning and end of each pumping period. Normally, the water column was sampled for FTOM at 0700, 1400, and 2200 hr, each for 2 hour duration. Sample volume could be determined since all pumped water was screened. Short (1-hr grab) FTOM samples were collected with this device. [NOTE: The samples were split into finer resolution size fractions after their initial collections. Therefore, the same sample time, sample volumes, and replicate counts are recorded for these various finer resolution size fractions within the broad FTOM category. J. Davis addendum]. Ultrafine transported organic matter (UFTOM) and dissolved organic matter (DOM) were obtained with the FTOM pumps. Three times per day, corresponding to the beginning of each FTOM sample period, 6 L of water were pumped into a 19L carboy. At the end of the day, the carboy was shaken vigorously and the water poured through a 52µm monofilament net. This water was filtered quantitatively under approximately 30mm Hg vacuum onto 3 pre-ashed, tared, Whatman GF/C filters (.45 µm pore size). [Note: They sometimes processed three UFTOM filters separately during a given day. J. Davis addendum]. Seston was removed from the CTOM and FTOM screens and frozen, after removing as much water as possible. The three samples per day of CTOM, FTOM, and UTOM were processed separately in spring to estimate diel variance for each size fraction. During summer and fall, the three daily samples were combined, yielding a single daily composite sample for each size. In the laboratory, CTOM samples were thawed and fractionated into 1-4 mm, 4-16mm, and >16mm subsamples prior to pigment extraction. Chlorophyll, dry weight, and ash-free dry mass (AFDM) for all particulate samples were determined as follows. After thawing, chlorophyll-a and phaeophytion were estimated using Lorenzen’s technique, with extraction in 90% acetone and absorbance determined on a Beckman DB-G spectrophotometer. Percent pigment degradation was calculated as phaeophytin divided by (phaeophyton + chlorophyll-a). Samples with acetone were transferred to tared crucibles, dried to a constant weight at 60ºC, then ashed at 525ºC for at least 4 hrs. Weight loss during combustion is reported as AFDW. DOM samples were concentrated to approximately 3ml by dreeze drying, and three replicates of each sample were analyzed using a Dohrman DC.50 Total Carbon Analyzer. DOM was assumed to be 50% organic carbon (Birge and Juday 1934). Stream discharge for each sample day was determined from stage: discharge relationships based on approximately 10 measurements (Buchanon and Somers 1969) made over the full range of flows at each station. Daily discharge values for the Salmon River at Stanley were estimated from a correlation between discharge at the discontinued Stanley USGS station and the active USGS gage at Salmon, Idaho, based on historic data from 1926-1960 (C. W. Alexander, USGS, Portland OR pers. comm.)." In addition, a second group was collecting samples using the 'grab' sampling method that was used during the 1978 and 1979 trips (see 1978 and 1979 methods). These 'grab' samples did not split transport into 8 size fractions, but instead collected bulk samples using 1mm mesh net (CTOM), 52µm mesh net (FTOM), and carboy collection of presieved water (UFTOM). In the datasheet, these samples do not report a specific mm size class, but instead list broad size categories (CTOM, FTOM, and UFTOM). These additional bulk TOM samples were not used in the original RCC organic matter dynamics papers.

1978 and 1979 Transport Sampling Methods and Site Locations In 1978 and 1979, they collected additional transported organic matter samples at sites throughout the Salmon River basin. These sites overlapped the 1976 and 1977 RCC sites, but also included additional sites in between the original sites. These additional sites included sites in the Salmon mainstem and also the actual tributaries. Sampling was conducted at a higher temporal resolution during 1978 spring run-off (i.e., multiple trips throughout June). This was conducted to assess how transport differed between the rising and falling limb of the spring hydrograph. Also, instead of continuous sampling over multiple days at each site as they did in 1976 and 1977, they sampled many of these sites for only an hour during a given day (these were termed quantitative 'grab' samples'). They would typically revisit a site over a couple of days, but only sampled for an hour during each site visit. The following methods are transcribed from the field notes of Tom Cuffney who was in charge of sampling in 1978 and 1979. The net opening was CTOM = 851.4002 cm^2 and FTOM = 506.75 cm^2. These samples were not size fractionated into 8 size classes, but were simply collected as CTOM (>1mm), FTOM (<1mm ≥52µm), and UFTOM (<52µm and ≥0.45µm). When this method is used, the datasheet reports these three broad size categories rather than mm size classes. "CTOM Sampling: CTOM was collected using a metal drift frame with an attached torpedo current meter and 1-mm net. This was placed with the long axis perpendicular to the substrate at all sites except Smiley where the shallow water depth necessitated orienting the sampler along the long axis parallel to the substrate. A measurement of the length of sampler out of the water was made to record water depth. This system was allowed to run for approximately 1-hr with the exact time of placement and removal recorded as well as initial and final readings on the torpedo meter. The volume filtered was calculated using the propellar count and sample duration. FTOM Sampling: FTOM was collected by running a 52µm net attached to a PVC collar with torpedo for 5 min. The net was constantly stroked to keep it from clogging. UFTOM sampling: UFTOM was collected in a 5-gal carboy, sieved through a 52µm net and collected on a 0.45 µm glass fiber filter (preweighed and ashed). [Note: In contrast to 1976 and 1977 sampling where they took replicate UFTOM samples, they typically only took a single UFTOM sample during each visit on a given day. J. Davis addendum]" Samples were processed for chl-a and AFDM during most trips. Standard methods were used for these analyses (APHA). When chl-a was not analyzed, the cells report a period. Sites were selected primarily for ease of access during the winter months. In general, the sites were named for the nearest tributary or town. Therefore, sites are at roads, bridges, and campgrounds. Sites in the mainstem, but near a tributary confluence, are indicated as such.
In 2011, the data were digitized from the original notebooks into Excel and PDF formats. An EML metadata record was created to accompany the dataset.
